title: How to Make Simple Ice Cream

methods.name: Making Rich and Creamy Ice Cream

steps.headline: Beat the heavy cream until still peaks form, about 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Pour the heavy cream into a mixer, and beat on high. This will give you a thick, creamy base for your ice cream. If you don't have an electric mixer, you can use a food processor fitted with whisks.

steps.headline: Stir together the sweetened condensed milk and vanilla extract in a large bowl.
steps.description: Make sure that the bowl is large enough to hold the beaten heavy cream as well.

steps.headline: Fold the beaten cream into the condensed milk mixture using a spatula.
steps.description: Keep folding and stirring until it is evenly combined.

steps.headline: Consider adding some goodies.
steps.description:
Gently fold in your desired additions or flavorings with a spatula. Be careful not to over-mix, or your ice cream will lose its fluffiness. Here are some ideas to get you started:
To make mint-chip ice cream, add a few drops of peppermint extract and a handful of mini chocolate chips. To make S'mores ice cream, add some mini marshmallows, crumbled graham crackers, and some chocolate chunks. To make cookies-n-cream ice cream, add 8 crushed Oreo cookies (or similar sandwich cookies).

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into a freezer-safe container and cover with a piece of foil.
steps.description: The foil will help keep the ice cream soft, and prevent ice crystals from forming. You can also pour the mixture into individual cups or bowls to make small, ready-to-serve desserts.

steps.headline: Freeze for 4 to 6 hours, and serve.
steps.description: Once the ice cream is frozen, you can scoop it out into small bowls using an ice cream scoop. If there are any leftovers, put them back into the freezer.

steps.headline: Add the milk, heavy cream, vanilla, and sugar to a blender and blend.
steps.description: If you plan on adding and liquid-y extras, such as chocolate syrup, do so now. Make sure all ingredients are thoroughly combined.

steps.headline: Add any chunky extras and blend again.
steps.description: Now is the time to add in some extra goodies, such as chocolate chips, crumbled cookies, or even sliced strawberries. Pulse the blender a few times until the new ingredients are just mixed in. If you are adding fruit, you can blend it until completely smooth.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into a freezer safe container.
steps.description: Cover the container with a lid or a sheet of plastic wrap to protect it from getting any ice crystals.

steps.headline: Freeze the mixture for 6 to 8 hours.
steps.description: For fluffier ice cream, stir the mixture every hour or so.

steps.headline: Serve the ice cream with an ice cream scoop and freeze any leftovers.
steps.description: The ice cream will last for about 2 weeks in the freezer.

steps.headline: Peel and freeze 4 to 5 bananas overnight.
steps.description: The more ripe the bananas are, the better your ice cream will turn out.

steps.headline: Cut or break the bananas into small pieces and add them to a food processor.
steps.description: You want the banana chunks to be about ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). If they are too big, they may clog up your food processor.

steps.headline: Blend for 40 to 60 seconds, or until the mixture is thick and creamy.
steps.description: Do not over-blend your ice cream, or it will start to melt.

steps.headline: Consider adding some flavoring and blend for another 10 to 15 seconds.
steps.description:
At this point, your ice cream is ready to eat, but you can take it a step further by adding some goodies, such as chocolate chips. Here are some yummy ideas to get you started:
To make mint-chip ice cream, add a few drops of peppermint extract and a handful of dark chocolate chips. To make chocolate ice cream, add 1 to 2 tablespoons of cocoa powder. To make strawberry ice cream, toss in a handful of sliced strawberries and a few drops

steps.headline: Serve the ice cream immediately, or freeze it for later.
steps.description: Scoop the ice cream out into small serving bowls using an ice cream scoop. If you aren't going to eat it right away, transfer it into a freezer-safe container and put it into the freezer; it will last for about two days. Keep in mind that because this ice cream is made from bananas, it will turn a light brown after some time.

steps.headline: Mix the ingredients in a blender until combined, about 30 seconds.
steps.description: You can also whisk them together in a bowl until everything is evenly combined.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into an ice cream maker and freeze it according to the manufacturer's instructions.
steps.description: Every ice cream maker will be a little different, so make sure that you follow the directions for your specific maker. If you don't have an ice cream maker, transfer the ice cream to a freezer-safe container, and freeze for 6 to 8 hours. Stir it with a spoon every hour. Keep in mind that the ice cream won't be as creamy.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture to a freezer-safe container and freeze it for at least 1 hour.
steps.description: Freezing the ice cream for 4 to 6 hours would be recommended, however. This allows the ice cream to "ripen." It will improve its texture and flavor. If you are not using an ice cream maker, then you cam simply pull your ice cream after the initial freezing time.

steps.headline: Serve the ice cream using an ice cream scoop and freeze any leftovers.
steps.description: If it is too hard, let it soften for about 15 minutes on the counter. The ice cream will last 1 to 2 weeks in the freezer.
